Questions.Question: According to the lesson, Sam realized BookShelf could support both Maya's cloud deployment and Chen's on-premise requirement by:
Options: Creating PostgresBookRepository and SQLiteBookRepository adapters for the same port
Questions.Explanation: Sam's excitement came from realizing that different adapters (PostgreSQL, SQLite) can implement the same BookRepository port, allowing different deployments without changing business logic.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, an HTTP handler that receives requests and calls the BookService port is an example of a driving (inbound) adapter.
Questions.Explanation: Driving adapters receive requests from the outside world and translate them into port calls. HTTP handlers, CLI commands, and GraphQL resolvers are all driving adapters - they DRIVE the application.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, which of the following are examples of DRIVEN (outbound) adapters? Select ALL that apply.
Questions.Explanation: PostgresBookRepository and SendGridEmailSender are driven adapters - they implement driven ports and connect to external systems. REST and CLI handlers are driving adapters that receive external requests.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, adapters can be _______ without changing the business logic, which is the key power of Hexagonal Architecture.
Questions.Explanation: The lesson emphasizes 'The Power of Swappable Adapters' - you can switch from PostgreSQL to MongoDB, or from SendGrid to Mailgun, without touching domain code.
